comments.commentBody: I didn't realize it was still 1950.
Dumb maybe, but hardly mentally disabled.

I haven't read the full opinion yet, but at first glance Justice Alito seems to be trying to pull a rhetorical slight of hand. That executing mentally disabled persons is not consistent with the Eighth Amendment is an issue already settled, and it was not an issue before the court.

The issue before the court here is whether a flat cut off at IQ 70 is really an accurate way to determine whether a person is mentally disabled. That calls for a medical opinion, not a moral opinion.

The courts have long relied on expert opinions on all kinds of technical issues, including medical ones. There was nothing inappropriate about the majority relying on the standards of professional organizations. Does Justice Alito think we should ignore medical professionals in favor of text message polls like it's Dancing With the Stars?
I love Stone beers, but prefer the Levitation--it has a nice malt backbone to balance the hops.

Love this article, as I too enjoy a great session beer. Thanks four the beer review Eric! If you like hoopier beer try Go To IPA by Stone Brewery. It has 4.5% alcohol, and is extremely sessionable. People are used to their 7.0% stuff, but this brew is just right.

Try a New Belgium Snapshot. Lightly spiced, lightly hopped (citrusy) wheat ale with a touch of lactobacillus for a subtle sour finish. Although not widely distributed in the Northeast.

Bell's Oarsman is also very good.
Some of them are not taking their drugs, which is likely part of the problem.

Couldn't have said it better myself. Some have argued that a person can still kill using another device such as a bat or a knife, but there is a better chance of the victim surviving than those who are shot at by a gun.
I watched Mr. Martinez make his statement on live TV. I was impressed at the clarity of his moral vision and the power of his condemnation even in the depth of his grief. I hope we will listen.
Richard Martinez seems to have more guts than the current big shots in Washington ever will.

"Fact: the second amendment permits gun control legislation."

No it doesn't. The bill of rights is about a set of "negative rights" government cannot grant. Does the first amendment permit speech control legislation?

"Fact: where there are strict controls on guns, there are fewer deaths by guns (see Australia, for example)."

Stricter gun control laws did not prevent mass shootings in Norway or Belgium - http://www.cnn.com/2014/05/24/world/europe/belgium-jewish-museum-shooting/

"Fact: most Americans support universal background checks, limits on high capacity magazines, and other reasonable measures."

No they don't. Liberals can't seem to understand most people don't share their views. Background checks are "reasonable", meaningless items like limits on "high capacity" magazines are meaningless.

"Fact: most Americans support universal background checks, limits on high capacity magazines, and other reasonable measures. "

The killer in this case had gone through three separate background checks. He didn't have high capacity magazines (they were ten rounds versus 17 rounds in the rest of the US). So again as in most of this mass shootings, any of your prescriptions would not work. What would is opening up HIPPA regulations so that those who have mental problems are required to be reported to police and added to the NICS database. But no, we can't do that. It would harm the rights of the mentally ill.

Most Americans don't count.  Loud, rich lobbying does.  Until that affront to democracy is dealt with there is very little that can happen.  The Personal Arms Race will continue and the NRA dictatorship will loom ever larger.

Well, here we go again. Fact: the second amendment permits gun control legislation. Fact: where there are strict controls on guns, there are fewer deaths by guns (see Australia, for example). Fact: most Americans support universal background checks, limits on high capacity magazines, and other reasonable measures. Fact - more innocents will be needlessly murdered unless tighter restrictions on guns are enacted.

This cannot be overstated..the situation is so bad that when we were traveling in Australia, a bright grad student who was planning on applying to US universities for his MBA, decided overnight that he will NEVER apply to American colleges. He woke up earlier the previous morning to the news of the Newtown school shootings. He said he could not conceive of a world where parents would be scared to send their kids to schools and colleges, not knowing if they will return home safely at the need of the day.
280 americans shot every day! In Japan: 1 per day.

Richard, I meant to say armed insurrection. Thanks for correcting me.

Since we are correcting things, you don't seriously mean to suggest people are just trying to score political points in talking about gun control? People are trying to save lives.

A knife doesn't cause mass murders, like when Adam Lanza used a Bushmaster Model XM15-E2S semiautomatic rifle to fatally shoot 20 children and 6 adult staff members at Sandy Hook. He couldn't create such mayhem and carnage armed with a knife.

I would absolutely agree that people with mental illness should have better treatment and be prevented from owning guns. Unfortunately, no one at the NRA is open to any idea restricting the types of weapons that are legal to own despite the enormous price we pay as a society for such availability.

Gun control works very effectively in other countries in reducing the number of murders and the scope of damage committed by deranged individuals. This is not in dispute.

People who are content with the status quo will continue to raise false equivalencies to confuse the issue.

I am thankful for people like former Mayor Bloomberg who has funded a political counterweight to the NRA to give politicians the courage to stand with the overwhelming majority of the population on this issue.

I encourage the public to stand with him. Who knows? The life you save may be your own.

Jacqui,

The Dixie Chicks are just rude!

David,

If this was about the victims some here would be speaking to the fact that knives, cars and even aircraft in the hands of terrorists or the mentally ill all kill people. Please note they are only commenting on the 2nd Amendment and the right to bare arms.

There are a number of comments, including your reply that compare us to Europe where there are fewer guns in private hands and, they claim less gun violence. This overlooks the fact that the governments of Europe who control most of the guns in Europe managed to murder at least 100 Million of their own citizens in the last 100 years, mostly with gun violence.

Our record while bad, is nowhere as bad as the rest of the world's where only the government is armed

Simply giving all the guns to "The Government" is not a good answer as is proven by history and current events!
Agreed. The NRA is no longer a participant in this discussion.

I think it is abundantly clear that the NRA will not support any sensible, common sense gun law so it is better to move forward without the leadership of this group.

Survey after survey show that by a wide majority Americans want sensible gun control. It is feckless politicians and a well funded gun lobby that condemn the nation to tens of thousands of deaths by guns a year.

There is no point in engaging this lobby that has shown no interest in any legislation that protects the public, from banning high capacity magazines favored by mass murderers to armor piercing bullets used to kill our police.

The Second Amendment clearly qualifies the right to bear arms by the necessity to keep a well regulated militia, better known as a standing army in 2014.

The quaint notion that an armed resurrection will overtake a tyrannical government is ridiculous in this day and age. The right to vote and specific laws regarding impeachment protect us today.

The idea of self-appointed mercenaries fighting the US government and its employees based on their own judgement of what constitutes tyranny is without a proper legal foundation and simply anarchy.

Let 80% of the country make sensible laws that dramatically reduce deaths by guns and make the NRA a sad asterisk in human history.
Most politicians care more about getting re-elected than they do about a rational gun policy.  Until that changes we're at the mercy of the N.R.A.

Hear, hear. It does indeed feel hopeless. So many people have been killed, so many families shattered, in so many different settings - schools, political rallies, libraries, shopping areas, on the streets, in their homes -- and nothing is ever done to change the easy access to guns 'n' ammo by anyone who wants to kill.
Chris Gallery
Isla Vista, CA
Is there any way that Fred Wilpon can be persuaded to make a bigoted statement into a recording device?

You are right in your analysis, but you left out one big point. Understandable since it's not an economic point.

Jobs that involve making life better for people tend to pay less and jobs that make things better for business, and the 1%.

This article misses an important point: the data compares *everybody* who has ever earned a college degree, and then makes a recommendation that *young people* should go to college.

For example, take two people who turned 18 in 1975; Mary went to college; Ben didn't. When the Mary graduated in 1979, she began making $40,000 (in present-day dollars) as an administrator; Ben, as a landscaper, only made $30,000. Today, Mary makes $80,000, and Ben makes $40,000.

Now, take two people who turned 18 in 2004. Leticia went to college; Neil didn't. When Leticia graduated in 2008, she couldn't find work for six months, and took a job as a bartender making $30,000; Neil, with his four years work experience in retail, made $40,000. Today, Leticia still works as a bartender and makes $35,000; Neil is making $45,000.

In our example, if we lump everybody together, the average degree-holder makes $57,500, and the others make $42,500. Using this article's logic, we should recommend that people continue going to college. Clearly, this logic is flawed.

Furthermore, this article provides doesn't examine the difference among majors. Social sciences and history are some of the most popular majors (http://nces.ed.gov/fastfacts/display.asp?id=37); I wonder if these graduates are making less money than non-degree holders, but STEM majors are making so much more that they overshadow the social science majors' lower pay.
So closing those mental institutions was magically irreversible?

Keeping guns out of the hands of people committed to mental institutions -- instead of anyone diagnosed with mental illness or disability -- is absurd.  In today's world, there are almost no  mental institutions left and almost no one is "committed" to one unless they want to be.
Fantastic idea. Let's do it.

California has some of the toughest gun laws in the country: An assault weapon ban, high capacity magazine ban, and universal background checks to name a few.  None of these laws prevented Elliot Rodger from obtaining his weapons.  The only gun control law that would have partially prevented his rampage would be a complete ban and the confiscation of the appx. 300M guns already in private hands.

who has access to automatic weapons?

the regulations to get one are so astounding, and most never bother to go through the steps, much less spend the money it takes to buy one.

perhaps the media hype and overall ignorance on the availability of automatic weapons is part of the issue.

1) No one should have access to automatic weapons.

2) We are all emotional people who can become enraged and lose perspective.....that's why access to all guns should be minimized.

Some companies like Actavis make deals at any cost.  Pfizer was smart to walk away from this in the current climate.  Eventually people will look at drug companies earnings again when the merger furry dies down.

You are so right on education vs credentials.

I share your learning experience. Though I don't even begin to speak any foreign language anywhere near as well as two of my daughters do.

Though I do have credentials, but I also have the years it took to gain them.

The advantage of college in the work marketplace may not be educations so much as it is credentials. That's really what people are paying for.

Thanks to the Internet, I've learned more Spanish language, American History and business than I ever did via formal eduation. I make a nice living writing code which wasn't even taught when I was in college.

I have few credentials but much education. Employers value credentials over education so I had to start my own company to extract my real value.
I don't see how you can justify having it both ways.  If it's good that certain secrets have been exposed, why should the exposers be punished instead of honored?

If people are cynical about Congress now just wait a few months. With five months to go prior to mid-term elections and control of the senate in question I doubt highly that anyone is going to get serious about gun control. Yes, there will be hand wringing and impassioned sound bites but in the end nothing will be done. This tragedy occurred in a state among the top five toughest anti-gun laws and yet here we are. People will point to the fact that Mr. Rodger stabbed as many people as he shot to death and that his vehicular mayhem was also a source of injury. If you are a Congress watcher just remember the air sickness bags are in your seat back pocket. It's going to nauseating.

The only explanation is - These studies must have been funded by NRA sponsored agencies. We have been desensitized and numbed by subjecting our kids to violence on TV, movies, vdo games. Hollywood keeps producing horror and crime movies because people watch them as fictional entertainment, they want their blood to race, totally oblivious of all the horror that exists in the world, for real.

I'm confused by your assertion that people in other countries don't commit gun violence on each other.
Because the guns in those countries aren't in private hands.

Don't you read or watch the news? As we speak people, in large numbers, are dying from gun violence in The Ukraine, Syria, the Sudan, Egypt and many other places. How is "the guns in the hands of the government" working out for them? How has it worked out for Europe over the last 100 years with 100 million dead, mostly from gun violence?
We live in a country with no war fought on our land except our own civil conflict. So you're saying you're up for some sedition and overthrow? Because otherwise I don't get your point.

What makes people crazy and violent?

What about all the Television shows with guns.

What about all the movies with guns?

What about the video games with guns?

What about the war stories about soldiers with guns?

Don't just treat the illness, stop the causes.

In Concord CA last weekend, a man was shot leaving a well-attended concert. The media has down-played this assault on the freedom of assembly that is threatened by this shooting, citing "police intelligence that this was not random, that the victim was targeted." As if that is supposed to make this assault on ALL of us okay. What about those who could have been hit in error? What about those traumatized by the sound or the sight? What about the concert promoter and the city of Concord's right to make money being hurt by people avoiding the venue due to fear of future gun violence? And on and on. When does this end?

The violent rhetoric of the NRA and their associates in congress must be called out for what it is-an attack on the freedom of peaceful Americans to go about their business without the fear of becoming a victim of gun violence.
The US is more and more resembling a third world country. In Iraq and Afghanistan we read of weekly car bombings and the call by shocked citizens to end the violence. In this country we read almost weekly of atrocities perpetrated by people with guns but, it seems, we are beyond being shocked. This is likely due to the fact that in the aforementioned countries they lack politicians who propagandize on their "freedom" to arm themselves and kill each other.
Mr. Martinez is exactly right. It is high time for the political establishment to get on with the work of actually protecting peace loving American citizens. And it is time to isolate the NRA in our society.
